KH.content: Derrida less concerned w/ art of Plato [re: mises en abyme of khōra and politics] but in a constraint, a programme, the being-programme of the programme, the being-logical of logic: Plato apprehends them as such, though in a dream, put en abyme
KH.linkedContent: Derrida less concerned w/ art of Plato [re: mises en abyme of khōra and politics] but in a constraint, a programme, the being-programme of the programme, the being-logical of logic: Plato apprehends them as such, though in a dream, put en abyme

KH.content: btwn text & theme, structure w/out an indivisible origin > theater of irony, w/out end, w/out bottom [abyss]; to isolate a theme, “philosophy-of-Plato,” would be to violently misrecognize, deny textual scene, questions of topology in general
KH.linkedContent: btwn text & theme, structure w/out an indivisible origin > theater of irony, w/out end, w/out bottom [abyss]; to isolate a theme, “philosophy-of-Plato,” would be to violently misrecognize, deny textual scene, questions of topology in general

KH.content: Platonism, which still can be referred to, would refer to the misprision, the thesis torn out by artifice from written fiction of “Plato,” and, under the name of philosophy, a certain force of thetic abstraction in his texts recommends one to do so
KH.linkedContent: Platonism, which still can be referred to, would refer to the misprision, the thesis torn out by artifice from written fiction of “Plato,” and, under the name of philosophy, a certain force of thetic abstraction in his texts recommends one to do so

KH.content: “Platonism” a necessary effect of Plato’s texts has dominated (in name of philosophy) by way of arbitrary violence (making the law) other motifs at work in the text
KH.linkedContent: “Platonism” a necessary effect of Plato’s texts has dominated (in name of philosophy) by way of arbitrary violence (making the law) other motifs at work in the text

KH.content: turns back against the text, w/ a violent reversion that’s always interested & interesting [says same thing about Nietzsche]
KH.linkedContent: turns back against the text, w/ a violent reversion that’s always interested & interesting [says same thing about Nietzsche]

KH.content: “Platonism” not only neutralizes Plato’s texts, inhibiting forces that continue to maintain a certain disorder (parasitism, ventriloquism, clandestinity, tone of denial), “Platonism” commands whole history of this neutralization, a philosophy would always be “Platonic”
KH.linkedContent: “Platonism” not only neutralizes Plato’s texts, inhibiting forces that continue to maintain a certain disorder (parasitism, ventriloquism, clandestinity, tone of denial), “Platonism” commands whole history of this neutralization, a philosophy would always be “Platonic”

KH.content: what is shown, hidden, won, lost in Plato, w/ Plato?
KH.linkedContent: what is shown, hidden, won, lost in Plato, w/ Plato?

KH.content: Plato never qualified khōra as matter (hylè) like Aristotle did
KH.linkedContent: Plato never qualified khōra as matter (hylè) like Aristotle did

GOD.content: Christian reversal, conversion of Platonism, entrance on scene of a “gift”  transforms Good into Goodness that forgets itself, love that renounces itself; this inaccessible source of Goodness means the donee also receives death
GOD.linkedContent: Christian reversal, conversion of Platonism, entrance on scene of a “gift” transforms Good into Goodness that forgets itself, love that renounces itself; this inaccessible source of Goodness means the donee also receives death

GOD.content: irreplaceable singularity of self [command of goodness] requires a death w/ no possible substitution “Death is mine if it is at all” [see p. 45 death creates possibility, p. 46 death is mine]
GOD.linkedContent: irreplaceable singularity of self [command of goodness] requires a death w/ no possible substitution “Death is mine if it is at all” [see p. 45 death creates possibility, p. 46 death is mine]

GOD.content: when Platonism, light or son of Good (invisible source of intelligible visibility) becomes Christian faith (a gaze)
GOD.linkedContent: when Platonism, light or son of Good (invisible source of intelligible visibility) becomes Christian faith (a gaze)

R.content: democracy acc. Plato [in Republic (Book 8)] looks to Derrida like a bazaar, a carnival, pre-capitalist marketplace, complete lack of authority, soft like Orpheus
R.linkedContent: democracy acc. Plato [in Republic (Book 8)] looks to Derrida like a bazaar, a carnival, pre-capitalist marketplace, complete lack of authority, soft like Orpheus

R.content: both Plato & Aristotle maintain political turn toward or salutation of One God, where arkhē has at his disposal tekhnē, for Plato not utopia, prayer, but very difficult
R.linkedContent: both Plato & Aristotle maintain political turn toward or salutation of One God, where arkhē has at his disposal tekhnē, for Plato not utopia, prayer, but very difficult

MONL.linkedContent: hyperbole is Plato’s word: excess beyond excess > impregnable, epekeina tes ousias

OOG.content: for Plato, wasn’t the eternity of essences another name for nonempirical historicity?
OOG.linkedContent: for Plato, wasn’t the eternity of essences another name for nonempirical historicity?

OOG.content: the Idea is not, always “beyond being” (epekeina tes ousias), as Telos of infinite determinability of Being, it’s being’s openness to the light > it is the light of light, sun of the visible sun, a hidden sun, no doubt what a Plato muted by Platonism tells us about

LOBL.linkedContent: scene of visibility: a primal scene > that which enables us to see should remain invisible, black, blinding [Plato]

MC.content: ever since Plato [repression of Democritus, a large symptom?], an organization of the throw: subject/object > repress chance, repress the mark, protect “normality,” isolate a solid context (stereotomy)

SPOM.linkedContent: Marx feigns to count ghosts, they are innumberable, and there is but one ghost (already too many, i.e. supplements), it is # itself, the arch-specter as father as capital or Plato’s good

VM.content: for Levinas, sun of epekeina tes ousias (fecundity, generosity) will always illuminate inexhaustible source of thought, Plato places Good beyond Being, beyond light of Being [see p. 312n Descartes’ infinite does this too]; “ex-cendence”

VM.linkedContent: is phenomenology really different from Platonic, metaphysical, idealism? Husserl would say yes, Plato hypostasized idea by not understanding it as noema

PP.linkedContent: Derrida recognizes that the cicada myth in Phaedrus also includes question about writing [before the Theuth myth], he asks: “has anyone ever picked up on it?”

PP.content: Plato presents writing as occult, suspect, power, just like painting, optical illusions, techniques of mimēsis in general > his mistrust for mantic, magic, sorcerers is well known
PP.linkedContent: Plato presents writing as occult, suspect, power, just like painting, optical illusions, techniques of mimēsis in general > his mistrust for mantic, magic, sorcerers is well known

PP.content: [Plato’s puritanical auto-immunity] illness as allergy to alien element, “normal” disease defends itself; God cannot have an allergic reaction > perfection and immortality: no relation to outside; but how can we exclude the parasitic supplement, pharmakon?
PP.linkedContent: [Plato’s puritanical auto-immunity] illness as allergy to alien element, “normal” disease defends itself; God cannot have an allergic reaction > perfection and immortality: no relation to outside; but how can we exclude the parasitic supplement, pharmakon?

PP.content: Plato attacks sophists for the substitution of mnemonic device for live memory, thing for limb, passive, mechanical “by-heart” for active reanimation of knowledge (truth must be distinct from its sign) > Plato dreams of a memory w/ no sign.
PP.linkedContent: Plato attacks sophists for the substitution of mnemonic device for live memory, thing for limb, passive, mechanical “by-heart” for active reanimation of knowledge (truth must be distinct from its sign) > Plato dreams of a memory w/ no sign.

PP.linkedContent: opposition btwn mnēmē and hypomnēsis institutes all oppositions of Platonism, the boundary line is major decision of philosophy, maintains, institutes itself, contains its fond advers

PP.content: pharmakon, older than either of the opposites, “caught (pris)” by philosophy, by “Platonism” > constituted as a mixture of two pure, heterogenous terms

PP.content: Plato speaks about writing from position of king? while suspecting non-“democratic” politics of writing
PP.linkedContent: Plato speaks about writing from position of king? while suspecting non-“democratic” politics of writing

PP.content: Plato prefers one writing over the other, a good writing over bad, a fertile trace (endgenders w/in) over a sterile one (une semence dépensée au-dehors en pure perte, risk of dissemination)
PP.linkedContent: Plato prefers one writing over the other, a good writing over bad, a fertile trace (endgenders w/in) over a sterile one (une semence dépensée au-dehors en pure perte, risk of dissemination)

PP.content: Plato condemns lost or parricidal son while acting like one [?]
PP.linkedContent: Plato condemns lost or parricidal son while acting like one [?]

PP.content: Plato moves dividing line btwn presence and trace (ikhnos) to dialectical trace and nondialectical trace: good play and bad play
PP.linkedContent: Plato moves dividing line btwn presence and trace (ikhnos) to dialectical trace and nondialectical trace: good play and bad play

PP.content: does Plato give play a chance, to take play seriously is to relieve it of its playfulness; Plato says (in Laws 803b-e) our life should be spent in play (sacrifice, song and dance), play perfectly [telos?]
PP.linkedContent: does Plato give play a chance, to take play seriously is to relieve it of its playfulness; Plato says (in Laws 803b-e) our life should be spent in play (sacrifice, song and dance), play perfectly [telos?]

PP.content: the 3 eras of “Platonism” (Plato, Saussure, and Rousseau), which put writing out of question while borrowing from it all its demonstrative/theoretical resources, must come to terms w/: 1) generalized sort of writing 2) a “contradiction”: written proposal of logocentrism 3) construction of “literary” work

PP.linkedContent: transmission of dialectical mastery of pharmaka from father to son disrupted by family scene that constitutes & undermines passage btwn pharmacy & house
